facts.text: Appellant addressed a public meeting of employees of the Defence Department on October 9, 1968.
In the course of his speech, appellant incited the employees to commit offences prejudicial to the security of the State or to the maintenance of public order.

Offending portion of speech: 'There will be hunger strike at Chavan Sahibs kothi No. 1 Race Course Road. If Chavan Sahib thinks that they will be in position to crush us with the assistance of C.R.P. and S.F. then that is his misunderstanding. Chavan Sahib when the Britishers had to leave this country then the same military and police will push you out. Because these children of military and police personnels are also hungry they also require bread for eating. Therefore, the day has to come when after their unity these workers will send you out. Comrades the Government suffered the moral death when it promulgated the ordinance. Because we had no idea of starting any violence, when we demanded bread, clothes and house. This struggle of ours will continue. If Government servants die then other labourers will take this struggle ahead. One thing more I want to tell you that if there will be no celebration of Diwali in the house of our fifty thousand people, then there shall be darkness in the houses of these ministers. I want to tell you Chavan Sahib that if your repression continued in the same way, one Udham Singh will be born amongst these labourers who will not live you live as Udham Singh killed Dyer after going to London.'

Magistrate, First Class, New Delhi framed charge against appellant on July 3, 1969 under s.9 of the Punjab Security of State Act (Punjab Act 12 of 1953) on perusal of documents filed under s.173 Cr.P.C.

Charge: 'That you, on or about the 9th day of October, 1968 at 4.30 to 5.55 p.m. near the Railway Pathak in the area of Delhi Cantt. made a speech at a public meeting organised by Delhi Defence employees in which you demanded or caused incitement to an offence prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order and therein committed an offence punishable under section 9 of the P.S. Act and within my cognizance.'
Appellant filed revision petition under ss.430 and 561A Cr.P.C. to quash the charge.
Delhi High Court single Judge rejected revision petition on February 24, 1972, holding prima facie case under s.9, but open to appellant to show otherwise at trial.
Special leave petition came up for preliminary hearing on August 18, 1972; notice to show cause issued.
Hearing adjourned on September 19, 1972 to enable writ petition; writ filed but special leave granted on September 26, 1972 on usual terms.

In January 1973, appellant filed criminal miscellaneous petition No.32 of 1973 seeking permission to urge additional grounds questioning constitutional validity of s.9 of the Act as infringing Art.19(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the charge framed under s.9 of the Punjab Security of State Act, 1953 should be quashed.
Whether s.9 of the Punjab Security of State Act, 1953 is unconstitutional and violative of Art.19(1)(a) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: The speech is protected by Art.19(1)(a); charge should be quashed as no prima facie offence under s.9.
S.9 of the Act infringes fundamental right of speech under Art.19(1)(a).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(a); Superintendent of Central Jail, Fatehgarh v. Ram Manohar Lohia

petitioner_arguments.text: S.9 should be narrowly construed like s.124A IPC in Kedarnath Singh, limited to incitement to violence or tendency to create public disorder.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kedarnath Singh v. State of Bihar; Art.19(1)(a) and 19(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Prima facie, remarks in speech amount to offence under s.9; open to appellant to disprove at trial via cross-examination or defence evidence.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.9 Punjab Security of State Act; State of Bihar v. Shrimati Shailbala Devi; Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar; Sudhir Kumar Saha v. Commissioner of Police

court_reasoning.text: S.9 falls within Art.19(2) as it covers matters like undermining security of State, public order, incitement to offence prejudicial thereto, and tendency to overthrow State, all permissible restrictions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only additional matter in s.9 beyond Art.19(2) is 'tends to overthrow the State', which is covered by 'security of the State'.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Superintendent v. Ram Manohar Lohia as s.3 UP Act materially different from s.9.
Rejected narrow construction like Kedarnath; s.9 comprehensively within Art.19(2); no need to limit to incitement to violence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Balance between freedom of speech and public order/security; no absolute freedom.

court_reasoning.text: At interlocutory stage, no serious legal infirmity in High Court order to interfere under Art.136; Magistrate to decide on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scope of special leave appeal not enlarged to merits absent grave injustice.

holdings.text: S.9 of Punjab Security of State Act, 1953 is constitutionally valid and within Art.19(2).
Charge not to be quashed; trial court to decide if speech covered by s.9.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court order refusing to quash charge under s.9 dismissed; s.9 held constitutionally valid; trial to proceed expeditiously.

key_quotes.text: "Prima facie, therefore, s. 9 clearly falls within the express language of Art. 19(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on constitutional validity of s.9

key_quotes.text: "There can be no such thing as absolute or unrestricted freedom of speech and expression wholly free from restraint for that would amount to uncontrolled licence which would tend to lead to disorder and anarchy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balances freedom of speech with public order

key_quotes.text: "It was open to the petitioner either by cross-examination of the prosecution witnesses or by adducing evidence in defence to show that in the circumstances under which these remarks were made they did not amount to an incitement to an offence prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court view affirmed; trial opportunity preserved
